TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the extraordinary level of volatile portfolio investment or so called hot money, exceeding some $2,000m which flowed into Australia last year and which was largely directed towards speculation in real estate, shares and the takeover of Australian industry. Does the Treasurer recognise the disruptive effects of these short term capital movements which aggravate inflation and force up interest rates? Rather than penalising Australian homebuyers, consumers and manufacturing and farm industries with the cost of more inflation and crippling interest rates, will the Treasurer immediately impose controls on short term foreign capital inflows?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is naturally watching developments on Australia's external account very closely. It is necessary, in responding to the present situation, to adopt an appropriate mixture of policies and not to rely overheavily on one particular response. The examination that I have had carried out and the up-to-date advice which is available to me does not indicate that speculation in real estate constitutes an undue element of the volume of private capital inflow that has come into this country in recent months. The honourable gentleman knows as well as other honourable members that it has been an objective of this Government-the objective has attracted a degree of bipartisan support on occasions around Australia-to establish a state of affairs in which this country is seen as a reliable and attractive country in which to invest, and is able to maximise the benefits of overseas investment whilst at the same time ensuring that the appropriate opportunities are provided for Australians to share in the resource development of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The responses to large private capital inflow are a number. It is currently not the intention of the Government to introduce the capital controls of the type mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition. It would, of course, be a very foolish person who totally ruled out particular responses in this area. I say to the honourable gentleman, as I have said on a number of occasions in the past, that earlier when these controls were introduced they were arbitrary and inefficient and were subject to very significant and legitimate criticism by Australian business. The Government has something of a preference in the present situation for relying on more general policy responses including, of course, the size of Government demands on our loan markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Treasurer. In view of the recent decision to allow interest charges on home mortgages to rise by 1 per cent, will the Government now amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to allow interest payable on home mortgages as a full tax deduction?

—It is fairly difficult for me at this time to say anything about the subject of taxation without getting people a little excited. Perhaps the honourable gentleman will excuse me from giving a direct response to his question at the moment.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: THE SHELL COMPANY OF AUSTRALIA LIMITED

TALK.START.PARA: —I also desire to put a question to the Treasurer. I refer him to last week's announcement that the Shell Company of Australia Limited has been asked to offer 25 per cent of its equity to Australian interests. Will the Treasurer tell the House whether naturalising status was discussed with Shell, in terms of a 25 per cent equity sale, or whether it is the intention of the Government to accord naturalising status to Shell once it realises a 25 per cent qualifying level of Australian equity? Will the Government grant naturalising status to Shell, or any other foreign company, without specific and irrevocable commitments to wind down the foreign equity to a maximum 49 per cent? Finally, does the Treasurer realise that, without such commitments, Shell with naturalising status would be in a position to take up 100 per cent equity in Australian projects where now it is limited to 50 per cent and naturally without diminishing the control structure one iota?

—The answer to the first part of the honourable gentleman's question is no. I simply repeat that an invitation has been extended to the Shell company to discuss the possible introduction of up to 25 per cent Australian equity in that company. It has not been made a condition of the two foreign investment approvals that I announced last week. So far as the naturalising rules are concerned, Shell is affected by those rules in precisely the same way as any other company. If it complies with the naturalising rules in every respect and wants naturalising status, it can have it. If it does not, it will not.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of a report in the Australian of 4 August 1981 dealing with the formation of the new Israeli Government, in which it is stated:

QUESTION.PARA: In another important move, the new coalition has agreed to proclaim Israeli sovereignty over the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip, ''five years after implementing autonomy'' for its Palestinian residents.

Has the Minister attempted to verify whether this report is an accurate statement of the views of the Israeli Government? If this report accurately represents the views of the Israeli Government, does the Australian Government approve of any proposal by Israel to annex unilaterally the West Bank or Gaza? If it does not, what steps has the Government taken, or will it take, to make evident its disapproval of any such proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article to which the honourable gentleman referred concerning the formation of the new Israeli Government and the likely policy of that Government towards the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip. The guidelines, which I understand have been issued by the new Israeli Government for the future of the West Bank and Gaza, include a declaration that the Government will work for the renewal of negotiations for full autonomy. This declaration is followed by statements along the lines that the autonomy agreed upon at Camp David means neither sovereignty nor self-determination. There is also a reference that, at the end of the five year transition period set down in the Camp David agreements, Israel will raise its claim and realise its act of sovereignty over Judea and Samaria, they being the historical names for the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

ANSWER.PARA: It is Australia's hope that the autonomy negotiations will recommence in the near future. We support the view that the outcome of these negotiations should make proper provision for the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people. As far as we can judge, the guidelines issued by the new Israeli Government appear to indicate a change in its approach to the negotiations and it seems as though this change will make it more difficult to make any progress in the negotiations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Did the Australian Government have any consultation with the Government of the United States before the decision was taken to produce the neutron bomb? If so, what was the official Australian attitude? Does the Prime Minister agree that, as this decision has dramatically accelerated the arms race and seriously jeopardised world peace, it is against the interests of all Australians and indeed all humanity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not surprise the honourable gentleman by indicating that I do not agree with the substance of his question or the conclusions contained in it. The threat to world peace has come from a Soviet Union that for decades has been spending 12 per cent to 14 per cent of its total income on defence and defence preparations. When United States expenditure on defence has gone down, Soviet Union expenditure on defence has gone up. Throughout the period of detente-a period when people, whatever illusions they were under, genuinely believed that the world was entering into a safer phase-the expenditure of the Soviet Union on arms went up. It spent 12 per cent to 14 per cent of its national income on defence and offensive weapons year after year. That has not altered. The honourable gentleman would need only to look at the buildup of Soviet arms in the Warsaw Pact countries-the number of tanks, aircraft and divisions-to know quite well that any hope of Western European security can be achieved only by having tactical nuclear weapons of one kind or another because, on the basis of conventional arms, there would be no hope in the world of any valid defence of Western Europe. If the honourable gentleman wants to take the position that Western Europe should be naked to the arms of the Soviet Union and the other Warsaw Pact countries, with their tanks and guns outnumbering those of the West manifold, let the honourable gentleman argue that in France, Germany or other countries in Europe.

ANSWER.PARA: It is worth noting that the new socialist President of France has taken a much tougher stand against Soviet militarism than was the case with his predecessor. Having in mind his socialist philosophy, I think we should give weight to what he and his Foreign Minister have indicated and said about the nature of France's policy in relation to those matters. Neutron technology is not possessed only by the United States. I understand that that technology is also within the possession of the Soviet Union. Tactical nuclear missiles are stationed throughout Europe. If there is available new weaponry which can be more direct in its impact with less fall-out in relation to people who otherwise would be in a sense innocents in a struggle than would be the case with the present tactical nuclear weapons, I think the honourable gentleman would be bold indeed if he tried to advance the argument that the Western powers-the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation powers and the United States-should leave the massive superiority in arms-conventional and, many would argue, nuclear as well-in the hands of the Soviet Union and its imperial empire. That is not the view of this Government. It would not be the view of the majority of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Health to the health insurance arrangements which are to commence on 1 September. Is he aware that one of the major Victorian health insurance funds announced this morning its new contribution rates? Can he say when the other funds will announce their rates so that the public will be in a position before 1 September to compare the rates of the various health insurance funds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted that a major registered health insurance fund in Victoria announced its rates this morning. I am very pleased that some of the dire predictions of the Jeremiahs, particularly in the Opposition, have proved to be ill-founded. In fact, when one takes into account the 32c in the $1 rebate available for people taking out health insurance with registered health insurance funds, the cost to the family will be less than the cost during the last financial year. I am very pleased to see that, in fact, this particular fund has come up with rates which are attractive and which, in fact, give the lie to some of those rather exaggerated statements which allege that the cost to the individual and the family would be excessive.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe there is a very urgent need for the funds to announce their rates as soon as possible. I would like to make it clear that the announcement of the rates must come from the funds themselves. Whilst I and the Department approve the rates we do not approve the timing of the announcement of those rates. The majority of the funds throughout Australia have lodged their applications for the approval of their rates. Those applications are being processed as quickly as possible by my Department. A number of major funds have had their rates approved and have not yet announced them. I would hope that they would announce those rates rather than try to secure some imaginary advantage by withholding the announcement. I hope they will announce them as soon as possible. I would hope that the funds that have not yet supplied my Department with their rates would do so as quickly as possible so that the public can have the opportunity to shop around. I might say in conclusion that the public have the opportunity to make a choice between competing funds. That element of choice is a very significant factor in the development of the new health scheme. That element, of course, would not be available under the Australian Labor Party's schemes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a statement made to Thai leaders in the last 48 hours by the United States Under Secretary of State, Mr James Buckley, that Washington would have no serious objections to a further military strike by China against Vietnam. Will the Minister protest to Washington in the strongest possible terms pointing out that a further military incursion by China into Vietnam would be against Australia's interests; that a war in that area would destabilise our region and would cause massive outflows of refugees which it would be beyond our resources to handle? Further, in the spirit of peace in the area, will the Minister urgently consider an Australian initiative, I suggest in concert with Japan, to promote negotiation rather than confrontation between Vietnam and the Association of South-East Asian Nations and thereby lay the basis for a peaceful settlement in Kampuchea?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not been able to get confirmation of the statement to which the honourable gentleman has referred. Obviously, Australia has a very direct interest in maintaining peace and stability in South-East Asia. I remind the honourable gentleman that, but for the Vietnamese invasion of Kampuchea, we would be in a much better position than we are in today. It is that country's invasion of Kampuchea which is the greatest single cause of instability in South-East Asia.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the honourable gentleman's suggestion relating to Australia acting in concert with Japan and in relation to the relationship between ASEAN and Vietnam, I remind the honourable gentleman that, amongst the outcomes of the recent international conference on Kampuchea, two outcomes were relevant. One was the establishment of an intercessional committee. It is expected that the conference will resume in due course after the United Nations General Assembly meeting some time next year to pursue the possibilities of a peaceful settlement in Kampuchea. Secondly, there was a declaration from the conference-I am not sure whether it is in the form of the declaration or part of the communique from the conference-that contact on a bilateral basis in the region should be pursued to see whether that process could lead anywhere. For our part we have made known to the chairman of the intercessional committee that Australia stands ready to assist in any way we can should we be asked to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Communications a question. As the Minister for Housing and Construction and I have recently discovered, the radio telephone facilities from Birdsville to the outside world are quite inadequate with only one channel operating. As the races are to be held on 4 and 5 September and as the right honourable member for Wannon may have to go camping there again after tonight, will the Minister please see that Telecom Australia upgrades this most important communications link to the people of Birdsville?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that the right honourable member for Wannon will need to go camping after tonight. However, he might well want to go to the Birdsville races for other reasons. There are about 44,000 Australians living in remote and isolated areas of Australia who virtually have no telephone services at the moment. There are significant difficulties in trying to provide telephones for some of those people. About 66 per cent of them, I gather, are Aboriginals, some of whom live a semi-nomadic lifestyle. Obviously it would be somewhat difficult to provide subscriber trunk dialling telephone services for them. Telecom has ideas of installing about two and a half thousand more automatic telephone exchanges. It hopes to have them equipped throughout Australia by about 1990.

ANSWER.PARA: Two new developments in this field will certainly help Birdsville and other remote areas. One of these is called the digital radio concentrator system, for which three trial equipment programs are now in hand. This system apparently provides a significantly improved access to radio in remote areas. Apparently the range of and the sound recorded on this digital radio concentrator system are considerably better than are now available on the high frequency service in operation. Telecom has high hopes that it will improve the services in the outback. In addition, in the first generation satellite there will also be some lines that will, I hope, extend the services in areas where the cost of land lines is now so high. I can assure the honourable member that, whatever the intention of the right honourable member for Wannon is in relation to camping or other matters, telecommunication services for his constituents and those at Birdsville and elsewhere shortly will be at least significantly better.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the Prime Minister's attention to the front page of today's Age which refers to the Zarb family, living in my electorate, with which I am acquainted and which lives in dire poverty. Since this family is typical of over two million Australians living below the poverty line set by Professor Henderson, I ask: Does the Government care at all about the poor in this country? When will we see action to help the poor of Australia who are the victims of this Government's economic policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague the Minister for Social Security will be making a statement in the Senate concerning a report prepared by the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat which is relevant to some of the allegations made in the honourable gentleman's question. I think there are a number of points that can and ought to be made. In introducing the system of family allowances, we redirected assistance in this country from the wealthy to the poorer sections of the Australian community. All honourable gentlemen will know quite well that the earlier system of tax rebates assisted better-off families in the middle to higher tax paying brackets and that there were many families not paying sufficient tax to benefit from the rebates then offering. A number of families which were not in the tax-paying arena benefited very significantly as a result of that social change.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, the budgetary provisions of this Government in the areas of the disadvantaged and the disabled have provided significantly greater funds as each year has passed. This Government introduced indexation of pensions and made that a matter of law to protect pensioners and those in need of help from this Parliament from erosion of their living standards. It is this Government which has assisted many organisations in the community to build record numbers of homes for elderly citizens so that they can live their old age in dignity and decency and with self-esteem. I know the thing in all this which hurts the Australian Labor Party is that many of these initiatives in the area of social welfare represent initiatives of an imaginative kind which the Australian Labor Party never even thought of.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Does the Government have any plans to socialise the means of industry production, distribution and exchange? Is there any way by which industry production, distribution and exchange can be socialised by democratic means?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the moment there are many countries around the world in very real economic difficulties. It is worth noting, I think, that whatever the political systems presently operating, government-run enterprises are the ones in greatest difficulty in nearly any country one could name. In many countries around the world, government-run enterprises in motor industries, in iron and steel industries and in coal industries are the ones absorbing vast sums of taxpayers' funds because of the inefficiency of the enterprise, because of the inadequacy of government management and because governments have felt that since they own the operation it is fair enough to pour taxpayers' dollars, billions upon billions of them, into supporting enterprises that were failing and unprofitable and which obviously should have undergone very substantial management changes and restructuring.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, if one wants to go to the socialist countries where everything is run by government, one can see a situation whereby the living standard of people is much less than that which is provided through the free market private enterprise system. Let me say only that this Government has no intention of introducing reforms of the kind contained in the honourable gentleman's question, reforms which I know the honourable gentleman was not advocating, and reforms which are very much part of the philosophy of the Australian Labor Party and which would have the direct result of lowering the living standard of every Australian family from one end of this country to the other.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REFUSAL BY SENATE TO PASS BUDGET

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his words and actions during the constitutional crisis of 1975 and again during the election campaign of 1980. I ask the Prime Minister: Does he maintain that the Senate still has the right and the role to play, if and when it sees fit, to refuse to pass the Budget? I ask also: If the Senate had no objection to the Budget being brought down tonight but felt that the Government's policies on interest rates--
—Order! The first part of the honourable gentleman's question is in order. The second part is out of order. It is a hypothetical question.
—Can I re-word it?
—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. I call the Prime Minister.

—Mr Speaker, if a Senate uses the powers that undoubtedly belong to it under the Constitution, quite plainly the party that uses those powers and the Senate that supports the party in the use of those powers will need to carry the argument before the people of Australia. It was the circumstances leading up to 1975-there is no need to re-open old wounds of which the honourable gentleman is well aware--

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The Prime Minister is now making the point that it was not the Budget in 1975; it was other circumstances. My point was-had I been allowed to finish the question-whether the interest rates policy of the Government would now be reprehensible.

—The honourable member for Port Adelaide will resume his seat. I have ruled, and I do not disturb that ruling, that the second part of the question is hypothetical and out of order. The first part of the question is in order and the right honourable gentleman is being relevant to that point.

—It was perfectly plain in 1975 that the people of Australia wanted the opportunity to exercise their basic and democratic right. They made a judgment in 1975 and confirmed that judgment overwhelmingly in 1977 and 1980-one of the record majorities that this Parliament has ever seen.
—In 1980? Cut it out. You just made it.

—I congratulate the Leader of the Opposition on securing his own position in recent times and, at the same time, securing a diminution in the number of members of parliament for the Australian Labor Party in the 1983 election. I think there is a warning to the Australian Labor Party. The Government of 1974 and 1975 caused great fear and concern throughout the whole Australian community. Therefore, there was an obligation on the parties which were then in opposition to do what they did. If the Australian Labor Party takes certain actions, those actions will be on its own head. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government's economic policy as evidenced by the recent rise in interest rates to the highest levels ever in the history of the nation.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday evening the Treasurer (Mr Howard) announced that interest rates controlled by the Government-that is, rates on bank mortgages, overdrafts of less than $100,000, government bond rates and semi-government authority rates-were to be increased by one per cent or by slightly more in some cases. This came as a shattering blow to millions of families in Australia. Already interest rates are at the highest level in our history-highest both in nominal and in real terms after taking into account the rate of inflation. Now they have been increased even further, making the fourth general rise in controlled interest rates in the last 16 months. During that period the bank mortgage rate increased by 3 per cent from 9 1/2 per cent to 12 1/2 per cent. The small overdraft rate-that is, on overdrafts of less than $100,000-increased by 4 per cent from 9 1/2 per cent to 13 1/2 per cent. Along with these rises we have seen similar rises by non-bank institutions, especially building societies and finance companies, which have meant that all home buyers and consumers relying on hire purchase to obtain household goods, cars and the like have been faced with mounting repayments. The Opposition utterly deplores these increases. They have a completely retrograde impact on people, on the income distribution in this country, on the rate of economic growth and on the level of employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at these matters in more detail. In regard to the impact on people, a rise in the repayments of home buyers and purchasers of household goods has the effect of reducing their living standard; that is, they have less disposable income after meeting higher interest repayments. For instance, for a typical household loan of $30,000 over a term of 25 years, a 3 per cent rise in interest over the last 16 months has added $65 a month to repayments; that is, over $15 a week. This is a crushing additional burden to bear. For those who can pay it, it means they have less income to spend on other items and therefore experience a decline in their living standards. For those who cannot pay it, it means selling their homes. Already we are seeing newspaper reports of families having to sell their homes because of their inability to maintain payments of these higher interest rates. For such people the decline in living standards is quite horrendous. It also means that many people who would have purchased a home at lower interest rates no longer can do so because the repayments required are too high in relation to their income.

Lending institutions generally will not lend if repayments amount to over 25 per cent of the gross income of the breadwinner. To borrow a typical housing loan of $30,000 over a period of 25 years one needs an income of $15,700 a year-that is, $302 a week. If one does not have that income one cannot meet the repayment requirements of the institution and therefore cannot get a loan. However, average weekly earnings at present are less than $300 a week-they are $284. We have a situation in which approximately 80 per cent of the income earners in this country are below the level required to meet the repayments required for a typical housing loan. We can say that four out of five income earners in this country are excluded from obtaining such a loan and therefore are excluded from the home buying market.

Apparently the Treasurer will not front up to this debate, but if he were here I would challenge him to deny that statement. He has denied it outside the House, but he clearly is absolutely incorrect. There is nothing that anyone on the Government side can say in reply which will refute the correctness of what I have said; that is, that the vast majority of the population are now excluded from the home buying market because they have to overcome not only a deposit gap but also a quite substantial repayments gap. This is an appalling situation. These clearly damaging effects on the Australian people show that the Government is totally out of touch with the needs of the people. It is so blinded by its monetarist ideology that it cannot see or does not care about the immense damage it is doing to the people.

The impact on income distribution also is important. It is important because savage rises in interest rates make the distribution of income in this country much more unequal. That is because the poor pay those higher interest rates while the rich benefit from them. People with only little savings or assets inevitably are borrowers if they want to make substantial purchases, such as a home, a car or a washing machine, and so they are greatly affected by rising interest rates. With rising interest rates and the rising cost of building accommodation, it is undoubted that rents also will rise, so they will be affected in that way.

People with little savings get little benefit from rising interest rates for deposits because they have little in the way of savings to attract that higher interest rate. People with substantial assets, however, gain from this process. Their savings will attract the higher interest rates on deposits and so their incomes will increase with rising interest rates. Because they have large savings or convertible assets they do not need to finance the purchase of a home, car or whatever by the means that have to be used by other people; that is, to borrow money. They are not adversely affected by the higher interest rates. In fact, they are better off. Rising interest rates redistribute income and wealth in a quite regressive fashion. They impinge savagely on the poor but benefit the rich. The Opposition is very disturbed about that aspect of rising interest rates.

The impact on the economy is also very severe. A large rise in interest rates quite clearly will restrict the rate of economic growth because of the impact on both investment and consumption. The overdraft rate has increased by 4 per cent. The prime rate for overdrafts of over $100,000 has increased even more. This must mean that investment is made more expensive because of the increasing cost of finance. Therefore, investment is less likely to occur and we are less likely to have the high rate of economic growth we previously had. With the higher cost of financing consumer expenditures it undoubtedly will be the case that fewer consumer goods will be sold than otherwise would have been the case and therefore there will be less economic growth in real terms from increasing personal consumption. In respect of investment and consumption, which have been the engines behind economic growth in the last year, we can see that there would be a downward impact on the rate of economic growth. Because of that reduction in the rate of economic growth it follows that there will be a reduction in the level of employment-at least the level that otherwise would have obtained. Because of less economic growth, fewer job opportunities will be created and therefore more unemployment will result.

The impact on the population of savage rises in interest rates is quite disastrous. Interest rises reduce living standards, force people out of their homes, force people out of the home buying market, worsen the income and wealth distribution, reduce economic growth and increase unemployment. In the light of all that it is amazing that the Treasurer seems to insist that it is proper and desirable that interest rate increases should occur. He says that if the Government is to be able to fulfil its borrowing program and to ensure that funds are available for housing we must have these increases in interest rates. He says that without them there will be no funds at all for housing. Let me make two points in regard to that matter. Firstly, it entirely sidesteps the fact that the policies pursued by the Fraser Government have brought about this situation of rapidly rising interest rates in the uncontrolled area and are creating pressures for continuing rises in controlled interest rates. Secondly, the rapid rise in bank and building society interest rates may make more funds available for housing than otherwise would have been the case, but who can afford it? Not the ordinary wage earner because he has this enormous repayments gap which I have already referred to. He is excluded from the market even if the money is available. Perhaps finance is being made available for housing, but only for high income earners, not for the vast majority of the population. I believe that these examples show that the Treasurer is totally out of touch. His wife said on television the other night that he knew nothing about the food and grocery bills of families. It is quite obvious that he knows little about family finances in general. If he did know something about them he would not make the absurd statements he has made about the need for increasing interest rates.

There are five key reasons why interest rates have risen. The first one is that the Government's continuing failure to achieve its money supply targets, while at the same time stressing the importance of their attainment, creates an expectation of increased interest rates being necessary. The Government, consistently over the last few years, has announced money supply targets and has mostly failed to meet them. Last financial year the money supply target rate of growth of M3 was 9 per cent to 11 per cent but the actual growth was 12.7 per cent, according to the Reserve Bank of Australia. Furthermore, if we use the broader measure, as the Reserve Bank shows in its annual report which is to be produced by the Government soon of M3 plus non-bank financial institutions, we find that the rate of growth of the money supply in this broader definition increased by 16 per cent in 1980-81.

Money supply growth has been way above target. The realisation of that in the market creates the expectation that eventually the Government will have to rein it in. Higher interest rates will be necessary to obtain that. Once that happens lenders will be reluctant to buy Government bonds or to lend to institutions with controlled interest rates, such as banks. So, the Government eventually is forced to raise bond rates and the bank rates. Although an increase in the money supply above the target rate may seem to reduce the likelihood of interest rate rises because it reduces the scarcity of money it can have the opposite effect through expectations of further interest rate rises being necessary to reduce money supply growth. Of course, that is especially the case where the Government announces money supply targets which are grossly exceeded.

The second reason for the increase is that the source of the increase in the money supply was also conducive to rising interest rates-45 per cent of the growth in the money supply in the last financial year came from the private external transactions, that is, the balance of private capital inflow over the balance of payments current account deficit. This large rise in the money supply from this external source, which is far in excess of its normal proportion, required increasing pressure on domestic credit sources to keep money supply growth down. That concerned bank lending in particular. It created further pressure for rises of interest rates and credit from these sources was made scarcer. So, rising interest rates were in part the result of a virtually uncontrolled capital inflow.

A third reason for the increase in interest rates was the greatly increased competition for funds as the resources boom developed. Business investment rose by almost 20 per cent. In this uncontrolled scramble for funds it was inevitable that pressures for and expectations of higher interest rates would develop. Fourthly, there was the deregulation of bank deposit rates which occurred last December and which sparked off a competitive scramble between banks and building societies for funds leading both of them to raise considerably their bank deposit rates and therefore provide pressure for higher lending rates. Of course, in respect of the banks that has now occurred.

Fifthly, there was the expectation of increased inflation despite the slight fall in inflation in 1980-81. There is a general expectation of higher inflation now. So we see that creating the basis for a further rise in interest rates. There were various reasons for interest rate rises. They all relate to the action or inaction of the Government. It is nonsense to pretend that it is just the operation of the market of which the Government is a helpless victim. What happens in the market is greatly affected by Government action and inaction. The severe rise in interest rates that has occurred in the past 16 months can be attributed to the Government because of its failure to control capital inflow, its failure to control the resources boom, its expected failure to keep inflation down, its deregulation of the bank deposit rate and its monetarist posturing that creates an expectation of higher interest rates.

The Government has taken some action which it says is aimed at reducing the pressure on interest rates. This has taken three forms: Firstly, a reduction in the deficit or an increase in the domestic surplus. In the financial year which has just ended the domestic deficit was abolished and a domestic surplus of some $428m was recorded-a turn-around of $1,000m. Whilst that was happening we have had interest rates soaring. So, this is a really positive and dynamic way to control interest rates. Whilst we have had a dramatic turn-around in the domestic deficit we have had at the same time spiralling interest rates. So, this is a thoroughly ineffective way of controlling the problem.

Secondly, we have had reductions in the real level of the semi-government borrowing program. This is said to be to reduce government competition with the private sector for funds but the increase in demand for funds has occurred much more in the private sector than in the Government sector. The fact is that the public sector borrowing requirement for State and local government is exactly the same percentage of gross domestic product over the last four years. Total public sector borrowing requirements is well below the level of a few years ago as a percentage of the GDP. The real level of government investment is no higher now than it was five years ago. It has been constant all of that time. Government investment clearly is not the source of increased competition for funds. The source is the private sector but the Government is doing nothing about that. The Government regards Government investment as something which is to be determined as a marginal addition to private investment with consequent damaging reduction in expenditure on the social infrastructure when private investment increases. There has been a failure to reduce interest rate pressure from that source.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sainsbury Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — There is no doubt that this is a matter of public importance. It is a matter which is being discussed by families, by businesses, by people who do not borrow or lend, right across Australia at the present time because it is one of the great problems of this nation especially in the minds of people who are already locked into a borrowing which requires repayment. The first thing I want to do is to acknowledge that the present high levels of interest rates in Australia are a great imposition especially on those young couples and home buyers who are locked into a loan program, who have fixed commitments and who now find that because interest rates are higher than they expected they have repayments which in many cases they are finding very difficult to afford. I acknowledge that. What we are talking about in the matter of public importance is what is alleged to be the failure of the Government's economic policy as evidenced by the recent rise in interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we ought to remember that even though thousands of Australians are experiencing this very severe and unexpected imposition conditions in this country-through the Government's recognising them with increases in interest rates in areas where governments have control-have been brought about by a number of factors, some of which have been outside the control of the Government and some of which, in fact, indicate paradoxically the success of the Government's economic policy. If it were not for the success of the Government's economic policy there would not be a record level of investment in this country. There would not be a very high level of confidence in this country which has led people to want to invest, to want to borrow money and, therefore in a market situation, to force up the price of money.

The honourable member Willis) acknowledged that the private sector wanted funds. He acknowledges that there is a very big demand for money. He acknowledges that the money supply is a factor which, if it is relatively small, will mean that interest rates on a supply and demand basis will go up. The honourable member acknowledges that public borrowing is still going ahead at the same high level as five years ago. All of this is academic to the home buyers who are competing in the market and for governments which are continuing to borrow at that same high level of five years ago.

The failure of the Government's economic policy is not what we ought to be talking about. We ought to be talking about the success of the Government's economic policy which has led to the high interest rates at the present time. If governments have failed in this area it is because, as I said, they are intervening in the market place constantly, wanting to borrow money, crowding out those people who ought to be getting the money, that is, individuals and people in the private sector. Governments have borrowed too much. This Government has been saying that for quite some time now at Premiers Conferences and publicly.

I must say that it took quite a number of years before governments of Australia understood what interest rates were all about, understood what causes an increase or a decrease in interest rates. It seems strange to me that even the public at large is now foolishly listening to people such as the Leader of the Australian Democrats in the Senate (Senator Chipp) who is saying that somehow we can miraculously control interest rates in the context of a controlled money supply. We live in a situation where, like the market for tomatoes, if there are a lot of tomatoes on the market the price drops; if there is a scarcity of tomatoes the price rises. Money is very similar to tomatoes, potatoes or other scarce commodities in the way it behaves in the market place. If there is a lot of money about-more than people require for their investments-lenders will not be able to demand as high an interest rate as they would if the other situation were to obtain, namely, confidence and a high level of demand for investment. Of course, there is some nexus between the level of interest rates and inflation. If inflation is running at a high level, lenders will want to recoup at least the cost of inflation on the investment of cash that they make and there will be an underpinning force in the money market for lenders to want a higher relative interest rate than they would otherwise want in order to recoup the real value of their money.

But leaving that aside, money involves a supply-demand price situation just as is the case in regard to so many other commodities. It has been acknowledged not only by this Government lately but also in many other areas of the economy that what I am saying is accurate. If the Opposition wants to refute that, it ought to refer to announcements made in New South Wales in the past few days. The Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, has said that if we do not increase the price of money coming from building societies in New South Wales there will not be enough money for the people who want to borrow it to build houses. That is exactly what we are saying when we say to the trading banks: 'We will allow you to raise your rates of interest for loans up to $100,000 because otherwise there will not be enough money for those people who want to borrow it'. In the context of the banking situation, I emphasise that the Commonwealth's announcement applies only to loans of less than $100,000 and that is the area in which small businesses operate. Those people want money and are prepared, apparently, to pay that interest rate, otherwise they would not approach banks for new borrowings. I re-emphasise that it is that smaller area of loans under $100,000 and loans to the housing sector in respect of which the Commonwealth has made its pronouncements.

As I said, Mr Wran has acknowledged the logic of the argument about interest rates by saying: 'Yes, we will have to put up the price of money to people borrowing for housing through the building society movement'. It seems quite fraudulent to me for the Premier to say that we can artificially mess around with interest rates. He is showing by his own actions that he does not really think that is true. I hope that in the lead-up to the coming election in New South Wales, Mr Wran will not try to pull the wool over the people's eyes by telling them that there is no logic in the money supply-demand situation. Mr R. B. Cameron, Director of the Australian Bankers' Association, in a bulletin issued yesterday, said:
Savings bank deposits showed little growth, in real terms, during 1980-81.
He went on to say:
Low deposit growth means a low level of lending for housing.
That is what we are talking about. If one is prepared to pay the price for money one will get it. Mr Cameron continued:
Savings banks will be able to provide a strong flow of housing finance only if they are able to set rates of interest in line with those applying in the marketplace.
Savings banks still do not have sufficient competitive freedom.
In fact, due to official controls, savings bank housing loan interest rates have risen over the past three years by much less than have other interest rates.

Taking into account the latest increases in officially controlled interest rates announced by the Treasurer last week, savings banks housing loan rates have increased, since December 1978, by 3 percentage points compared with larger increases on the following marketable securities:

He spoke about interest rates on government securities, et cetera, which have gone up much higher. Mr Cameron is saying that housing loan interest rates have not gone up as rapidly as other interest rates. At the same time, he is pointing out that there is less money available for housing than there ought to be. He confirms what I am saying, that is, that if we do not recognise the supply-demand situation we cannot hope to act in the market place to see that those people who need money in specific areas will have it. It is as simple as that.

So we cannot lower interest rates artificially. Of course, if there were some mechanism by which we could do that and, at the same time, tell the truth to the people that it is possible to lower interest rates in the long term, heaven knows, any government in this country would want to do it. No government wants high interest rates, but we cannot go against the fact that a lot of people want money at the present time. As the honourable member for Gellibrand said, Australia is turning out to be a wonderful place for people to invest. Of course, the old furphy of money coming in from overseas has to be raised. It is an emotional issue of selling off the farm, speculating in Australian land or whatever the Australian Labor Party uses to try to get people's emotions going. The fact is that money is coming into this country because Australians want to use it to invest in this country or other countries want to use it to invest in this country. There is a great revival going on in our industries that, hopefully, will not be cut short by many of the problems that we are facing, simply because people know that this is a very good country in which to invest. Not the least of these are the people of Australia who live and work here. That revival is the means, surely, of creating the jobs that we are looking for.

Hopefully, when interest rates find a level where people will say: 'Look, I do not want to invest', they will stop borrowing. That is the supply-demand situation. When interest rates get to a level of 15 per cent or 18 per cent, or whatever percentage it is, and people decide that it would be better not to borrow to invest but to leave the investment alone, then interest rates will even out. At some later stage, interest rates will drop when people decide that investments at the level at which they are being made at the present time perhaps are not as important as consumption or some other use of money. All those things will remain to be seen. In the present situation, however, I have to agree with Mr Cameron. If money is to be available for those people who want to invest, we must live in a society that reflects the market. At last we are beginning to do that.

In November last year the Government began to recognise the supply-demand situation by relaxing, to some extent, the interest rate regime for trading banks. We are also realising it by trying to keep pressure on the States and on ourselves to lower the amount of public sector borrowing. That only helps to crowd out those people who otherwise want to invest and therefore reduces the supply of money to those people.

All of that is academic to the home buyer, the person who has already bought a home, the person in the squeeze. What I do hope is that in our country rather than listen to gobbledegook from people who think that we can artificially keep interest rates down, the Australian people understand that we are all in this together. We should ask ourselves: Should the houses that we have built in the last 10 or 15 years have been a little smaller than they are or should they be a little smaller in the future? Are we making the decision in Australia at the present time that we would prefer to invest in resources or manufacturing capacity and not to invest so much in houses? These are the things that people will make decisions about if they are given a market place in which to make those decisions. Another question that the Australian people are beginning to ask themselves about in regard to interest rates is: Can we support the level of government crowding out of the private sector that we are experiencing at the present time? The weight of Australians should get behind our Government in limiting government and keeping it small. The people should also get behind us in trying to lower inflation which is the other big factor in the increase in interest rates through their actions in the market place-the wages market place, in the profits market place and in the places where people push up prices to their own detriment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue which we are debating today is one of crucial importance to millions of Australian families. The steep rises in interest rates on home loans which have occurred in the last few months including the rise of a further one per cent announced last week have had and will continue to have a severe impact not only on those families but also on the Australian economy as a whole. Indeed, the interest rate rises will further intensify the economic crisis of this nation, increasing dramatically the tensions between capital and labour, increasing the gap between the rich and the poor and increasing the level of unemployment. The very fact that the Government proceeded with such a destructive policy notwithstanding the opposition from substantial sections of business as well as the whole of the labour movement shows that it is completely trapped in the fantasyland of its own economic policies which, to quote the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), do not take into account the human consequences of their implementation. It is these human consequences that I want to focus on before talking about the broader economic consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Age put it on Saturday, 15 August: 'Living standards to be hit by rise in home interest'. This is because the average Australian family will be struggling to find an extra $65 a month on home repayments. Everyone will be paying about a third more on repayments than they were 15 months ago. A family with a $30,000 loan will have to repay $98,000 as distinct from $79,000, an increase of $19,000. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) pointed out recently, a $30,000 loan is now out of reach of four out of every five wage earners. This is because the proportion of what is required to pay for a home loan has risen from 26 per cent to 34 per cent of after-tax income. Many families who already had trouble meeting previous payments will be forced with the new increases to sell their homes and attempt to find rental accommodation.
To illustrate the plight of many Australians, I will read this letter:

Dear Sir, In my name and in the name of my family I am coming to you for help. Three years ago my wife and I had a healthy life, and decided to purchase a house, like all other people. Just after purchasing the house I got very sick and am now a pensioner. House repayments were $260 p.m. and we could manage that amount. Now my wife is sick and the payments on the house have risen to $360 p.m. This situation has caused us to come to you for help.
We are pleading to you to make our house repayments less. If we lose our house we lose everything. We have two children aged thirteen and ten years and are all in a very sad situation.
We wish to tell you about our other bills like gas, electricity, insurance, telephone, registration which we have to manage also. We are left with $20 per week for food for four people.
Our children live in hope that a better day will come tomorrow, but tomorrow never comes.

I shall send a copy of this letter to the relevant Minister. What all this adds up to is that the Government has now clearly abandoned the millions of ordinary Australians whose dream it has been to purchase a home and to pay for it at a reasonable rate.

All the propaganda of the Liberal Party including its pretence to represent the middle class Australians who have invested their life savings in their homes is now exposed for what it is-a lie. I say this to all fellow Australians: This Government has sold out 95 per cent of us to the interests of the foreign corporations. The interest rate rises and their consequences show that this Government cares nothing for the welfare of the people it is supposed to represent. This Government claims that the rise in interest rates is necessary because there is insufficient money available for government and semi-government borrowings. Yet this situation has come about at a time when a record $6,500m of foreign capital came into this country in the last year.

It should be clear that it is not the lack of funds as such which has led the Government to its decision. There is a lot of money available. Rather, it is the way in which the Government has handled its monetary policies which has resulted in the present situation. On the one hand the Government has a totally open door policy on foreign investment. Foreign capital can come into Australia and be used for any purpose whatsoever. As a result, of the $6.5 billion that came into Australia, less than 25 per cent went to new resource development. Most of it went into real estate speculation, into buying Australian land and property and into take-overs of Australian firms. This is documented. Much of it is simply an attempt to make fast profits by gambling on a further evaluation of the Australian dollar.

This Government has persisted with the myth that the destination of the capital inflow was towards resource development. To sustain this mythology, the Government, together with State governments, has borrowed millions of dollars to build infrastructures such as roads and power stations to support this resource boom. This has brought about substantial pressure for interest rate increases; yet it ignores the simple principle that most of these infrastructure developments should be financed by the companies themselves if they are serious about resource development. It is interesting that honourable members opposite talk about free enterprise doing everything and yet we have all this infrastructure support by State and Federal government. The basic point is that the way in which resource development has been handled by this Government has resulted in a reduction rather than an improvement in the standards of living of ordinary Australians, and the trend will continue unless the Government changes course.

There is a further cause for the rise in interest rates. While the Government refuses to intervene in any way to control the level and direction of foreign investment, it has strongly intervened to attempt to limit the growth in the money supply. As a result of this heavy intervention, the availability of money for housing and government programs has been reduced. The ideological incoherence of the Government is added to by a further factor. It has ended intervention in the regulation of bank borrowing rates, which as the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) has pointed out, has made the interest rate problem much worse. What we have here is a pattern of non-intervention in areas where there should be substantial regulation and heavy intervention is an area where there should be more flexibility, that is, in the money supply. The government is thus pursuing the complete opposite of rational policies to limit the interest rates.

No doubt the Treasurer (Mr Howard) will tell us tonight that he proposes to reduce government expenditure in real terms and achieve a domestic Budget surplus. He will try to tell us that this is the way to control interest rates. We believe that not only is this not the case but also that this further attack on government services and the refusal to provide increases in social security payments will substantially reduce living standards and increase poverty. In other words, the people will suffer not only through the increased interest rates but also through the Government's attempts to control them. The Government has put the people in a totally unwinnable situation with its policies.

What are the consequences of this policy on the economy? Because of the cutbacks in spending, unemployment will increase. Furthermore, because the disposable income of families is dramatically reduced consumption will fall. People will not be able to buy as many goods and services. This will result in losses in production and further unemployment. What are the consequences for industrial relations? As the media has noted, a crisis is developing in this area as unions push for increases to cover the increased costs of interest rates to their members. Mr Dolan of the Australian Council of Trade Unions has made it clear that this is a legitimate demand by workers. The tensions which will be created in this country as a result will certainly increase, and the Government is to blame. Where is the Government going in future with interest rates? The Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System has recommended the complete deregulation of interest rates. If the Government does this-and it is consistent with its absurd philosophy-interest rates will go through the roof. We warn the Government against this course. It has no mandate for this policy and no democratic right to impose these further burdens on the Australian people.

What should a rational government be doing about interest rates? It should attack the causes of this phenomenon-namely, an excess of money going into speculation and useless, unproductive actions which do not create employment while insufficient money is going into establishing new enterprises, new projects and worthwhile social needs. There needs to be a direction to the banks and lending institutions to provide a proportion of their funds for home loans at adequate interest levels. Since the banks and lending institutions are given special licences and are protected by law--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hyde Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt-I am sure that no one on this side of the House will deny it-that the present high level of interest rates is causing extreme difficulties for those people who are purchasing homes and who have low equities and high mortgages. However, the debate is not helped by the confusion of cause and effect, circular argument or the advocacy within one speech of policies that contradict each other. The contributions to the debate of the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) and the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) did those things. They were longer on emotion than on a rational assessment of the position.

SPEECH.PARA: The interest rate is but the price of money. I do not think that the honourable member for Gellibrand would quarrel with that statement. The price of money, like anything else, is affected by supply and demand. It is not possible to avoid that problem by trying to put a strait-jacket on what is defined as money or to put a strait-jacket on its price, that is, to say by fiat that interest rates will reach only a certain level. The British tried this and what happened was exactly what one would expect to happen. Various substitutes for money arose outside the market and other liquid assets took the place of money. The British did not in fact manage to reduce the effective interest rate for those people who were most in need. They were the very people who were forced to use other sources of borrowing. We should look at the supply of money and the demand for it. In doing so, I think it helps if we make a distinction between real and nominal interest rates. The real interest rate is the difference between inflation and the quoted price for money in the market. If the real interest rate is negative, people will not accept financial assets. It is not possible to raise money.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are certainly not negative now.

—No. I will come to that. That is quite correct, but if we increase the supply of money we will increase the inflation rate quite quickly. The inflation rate is part of the nominal interest rate. I agree that we will temporarily reduce the real interest rate. However, because we have increased the inflation rate we will substantially increase the nominal interest rate and the amount of money that the home buyer has to find. So increasing the supply of money is not a solution. The honourable member for Gellibrand accepted that in the latter part of his speech when he criticised the Government for its approach to money supply targets and its failure to meet them. That was the one part of his speech with which I agreed. Therefore, the Government-any government-is left with the alternative of reducing the demand for money. Currently the demand for money is very high and that is reflected in high real interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: Interest rates are high primarily because Australian investment is seeking to raise capital on the Australian money markets to invest for our future. That is our future wealth. The rate of economic growth is higher now than it has been for six or seven years. For the first time in a long while substantial capital is being invested in Australia's future. That is a good thing. It is reflected in rising rates of employment. Employment has risen by 2.3 per cent in each of the last two years. They are facts which cannot be denied. Unemployment has fallen in the last 12 months. The important thing is that employment has risen. Not only has the stated unemployment rate fallen but also a higher proportion of Australians have entered the work force. Yet it is this investment, this increased economic activity, which above all else is putting pressure on the Australian capital market. What can a government do about that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop it.

—A government could stop it. The surest way of stopping it would be to depress the present buoyant state of Australian investment by reducing confidence in the economy so that Australian investors would no longer want a stake in Australia's future. That would stop it, but it would also increase unemployment rates and leave a much poorer Australia. One thing that the Government can and should sensibly do is take its own borrowing requirements out of the market. At least it should reduce its own demand for borrowings. It can do this by either raising taxes or reducing its own expenditure. There are no other alternatives. Opposition members cannot have their cake and eat it. They have to come down on one side or the other. If they want higher government expenditure and lower interest rates, there is one course left to advocate; that is, higher taxes. If that is what Opposition members want they should be honest and spell it out.

SPEECH.PARA: I now want to say something about living standards. For every borrower there is a lender. Are Opposition members asserting that borrowers are poorer than lenders? The statistics do not support this. I ask honourable members to think about their own families. I think they will conclude that their kids are likely to be net lenders while they are net borrowers. Honourable members should look around at their own electorates and think about what the people do. The net borrowers tend to be the more wealthy people and the net lenders tend to be those who have small fixed interest accounts. They are very often old people or young people. I am not suggesting that rapid changes in the price of money-the interest rate-do not cause a problem. They do; but the problem is not regressive.

The honourable member for Gellibrand made a fair criticism of the Government when he said that it had not met its money targets. That is true. Because of that the interest rate was forced to move further at a later time than it otherwise would have had to. To that limited extent, I accept the honourable member's criticism. He had quite a lot to say about capital inflow. To the extent that capital inflow is not matched by goods coming into the country-I have not noticed the Australian Labor Party advocating a vast increase in imports, although I would recommend the removal of some of the barriers to imports-it increases the money supply and reduces the price of money. That is the first effect. That effect can be neutralised by further government borrowings. At one stage the honourable member for Gellibrand seemed to be advocating the monetarist approach and at another stage he seemed to be denying it. He should make up his mind about which camp he is in. The initial effect of capital inflow is to reduce interest rates, but if the Government is to meet money supply targets the effect is neutralised.

The Whitlam Labor Government did not have any money supply targets and the money supply blew out by 26 per cent. The inflation rate rose to around 17 per cent and, of course, interest rates screamed up after it. The option available to the Government is to reduce its own pressure on the money markets, to stop competing with the householders and the small businessmen. That option is being pursued by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 8 to 12 (1981).

The Customs Tariff Proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1966. Proposals Nos 8, 9 and 10 formally place before Parliament, as required by law, tariff changes made by Gazette notice during the last recess. The changes contained in Proposals Nos 11 and 12 are new and arise from the Government's decisions in relation to developing countries preference quota levels for 1981-82 and the Industries Assistance Commission's report on Miscellaneous Transport Equipment.

Proposals No. 8, which operates from 1 January 1982, contains changes resulting from the Government's decision on recommendations made by the IAC in its report on Textiles Clothing and Footwear. In this case, the Government decided not to accept the recommendations of the IAC because of the loss of employment that would result. A new program of assistance for these industries will apply for a period of seven years from 1 January 1982. This will supersede interim arrangements which have applied to some goods since 1 September 1980. The new tariff structure was notified by Gazette on 24 June 1981 to facilitate preparation by importers for new tender quota schemes.

The changes in Proposals No. 9, which operates from 8 July 1981, implement the Government's decision in relation to the report by the IAC on Lamps and Lighting Fittings (Developing Country Preference). The decision reduces the developing countries preference margin to 10 percentage points for lamps and lighting fittings from the province of Taiwan. Other developing countries will retain current preference margins.

Proposals No. 10, which operates from 15 July 1981, is an administrative change in relation to certain disposable shopping bags of artificial plastic material. These goods have been reclassified from tariff item 39.07 to tariff item 42.02 following a decision by the Customs Co-operation Council. The rates now provided in tariff item 42.02 restore the levels of protection that existed prior to the re-classification.

The changes in Proposals No. 11 are operative from 1 July 1981 and follow the Government's review of the developing countries preference quota levels for 1981-82. The effect of these changes is, in the main, the removal of developing country preference quotas on a number of products.

Proposals No. 12 contains changes arising from the Government's decision to accept recommendations made by the IAC in its report on Miscellaneous Transport Equipment and is operative from tomorrow. The decision means:

Phased reductions in duty to a long term rate of 20 per cent for bicycles and certain bicycle frames, to 25 per cent for hand-propelled vehicles and certain wheeled toys designed to be ridden by children, and to minimum rates for many bicycle components;
minimum rates for motor cycles and most motor cycle parts; and
a duty of 25 per cent on animal drawn vehicles, on parts for hand-propelled or animal drawn vehicles and on parts or accessories for toy bicycles, tricycles, et cetera.

Proposals No. 12 also contains a number of administrative changes which do not alter rates of duty. A comprehensive summary setting out the nature of all changes has been prepared and is being circulated to honourable members. I commend the Proposals to the House.

Let me read one of them:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
Whilst not opposing the Bill-
The Customs Tariff Validation Bill-

The House is of the opinion that a Parliamentary Standing Committee on Tariffs and Excise should be established to examine each change in tariffs and excise following the gazettal of proposals or their being introduced into the Parliament on the one hand and before related Bills are introduced into the House on the other hand.

However, on this occasion I got up on the spur of the moment not only to say these things but also to say something about the particular Proposals. The Government accepted that advice and, in the absence of any submissions from those affected being made to me or to other members of the Opposition, who have not passed any submissions on to me, so do we on this side of the House accept those Proposals. I had to make a decision as the Minister spoke as to what I should do on this occasion. Frankly, from what he has said, I am unable to say one way or the other whether the Opposition accepts or rejects the particular matters put forward. On this occasion, if my ears served me correctly and I heard what the Minister had to say a few moments ago, the Government has not accepted the recommendation of those who have looked at this matter in depth. What an absurd way to do business. As I have said, the procedures have gone from bad to worse. I am not sure that I explained fully earlier that previously at least we had these Customs Tariff Validation Bills before us twice a year, but now the Government has changed this procedure and we are going to have Customs Tariff Validation Bills before us only once a year. Probably in this case the Parliament will next be able to debate and make known any individual opinions on Proposals 11 and 12, which it has only just heard about, in about next May or June which is probably when the validation Bill will be introduced. I regret that as much as I enjoy the company and appreciate the person of the present Minister, on a professional basis I have to say that he has gone from bad to worse in this matter and that he is not improving things. TALK.START.PARA: —But you have said that the debate is useless.

—I am helped by another interjection from the Minister. Unfortunately, others will not have heard it; so I will repeat it. He said that I have said that the debate is useless.
